nodes.text: IoT-based smart home systems can simultaneously enhance energy efficiency and security, enabling intelligent and sustainable living spaces
IoT architectures for smart homes combine sensors, actuators, controllers, and communication protocols (ZigBee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi, BLE, Thread) to enable monitoring and automation
IoT-enabled energy management (smart thermostats, smart lighting, smart plugs, EMS) reduces household energy consumption by up to 30% in reported studies and case examples
IoT security measures (end-to-end encryption, authentication, blockchain, ML-based intrusion detection) significantly reduce device compromise and response times to attacks
Significant challenges limit IoT smart home potential: device interoperability fragmentation, high initial costs, security vulnerabilities, scalability and network congestion
System design uses edge-capable controllers (Raspberry Pi, Arduino with local AI) to reduce latency and enable local automation and predictive maintenance
Communication networks are chosen by application: low-power protocols for sensors and control, Wi-Fi for high bandwidth tasks, and newer protocols like Thread for IPv6 scalability
Evidence from field studies: smart thermostats saved 10-12% heating and 15% cooling; a 2022 California study of 1000 smart thermostats saved 1.2 GWh in one year
AI and ML in energy management enable predictive analytics, demand response, and dashboards that can reduce consumption further (McKinsey: 20-25% reductions; IRENA: 30-40% for IoT-integrated solar)

Evidence for security gains: proper encryption reduces IoT device compromise (Symantec report 70% fewer compromises), blockchain frameworks claim up to 50% risk reduction, and IDS reduces response times from hours to milliseconds
Methods for security include AES-256 end-to-end encryption, two-factor and biometric authentication, blockchain device verification, and ML-based anomaly detection and IDS
Interoperability and standardization gaps arise from proprietary protocols and fragmented ecosystems, causing compatibility issues in multi-vendor networks and security exposures

Economic and operational limitations: average upfront cost per household for IoT energy solutions is about 1500 to 2000 USD, and existing protocols and cloud reliance create scalability and latency problems

Recommendation: adopt standardized protocols (Thread, Matter), regulatory frameworks and subsidies, and invest in R D for lightweight encryption, edge computing, federated learning and interoperable systems

Future trends that can address challenges: 5G/6G, edge computing, AI, blockchain, quantum cryptography, and IoT-powered microgrids and VPPs to improve performance, security, and integration with smart cities
